current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

external-xref.#tail:
of title 41, United States Code (popularly referred to as the Buy American Act)
			 and certain other laws with respect to certain waivers under those laws,
			 to provide greater transparency regarding exceptions to domestic sourcing
			 requirements, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Short title

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is amended by adding at the end the following new
			 paragraph:

header.#text: Increase of domestic content percentage to 60 percent

text.#text:
Articles, materials, or supplies shall be treated as made substantially all from articles,
			 materials, or supplies mined, produced, or manufactured in the United
			 States, if the cost of the domestic components of such articles,
			 materials, or supplies exceeds 60 percent of the total cost of all
			 components of such articles, materials, or supplies.

header.#text: Substantially all

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is amended by adding at the end the following new
			 subsection:

header.#text: Criteria required for use of overseas exception
Criteria for use of overseas exception
In general

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
for articles, materials, or supplies to be acquired for
			 use outside the United States may not be used unless one of the following
			 criteria is met:

text.#text: The exception under
The articles, materials, or supplies are needed on an urgent basis.
The articles, materials, or supplies are to be purchased using a local supplier.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
demonstrates that the articles, materials, or supplies
			 to be acquired (if acquired from a company manufacturing in the United
			 States) would be more than 50 percent more expensive for the Federal
			 agency acquiring the articles, materials, or supplies.

text.#text: A cost analysis described in

In any case in which articles, materials, or supplies are to be acquired for use outside the United
			 States and are not needed on an urgent basis or are not to be purchased
			 using a local supplier, before entering into a contract an analysis shall
			 be made of the difference in the cost of acquiring the articles,
			 materials, or supplies from a company manufacturing the articles,
			 materials, or supplies in the United States (including the cost of
			 shipping) and the cost of acquiring the articles, materials, or supplies
			 from a company manufacturing the articles, materials, or supplies outside
			 the United States (including the cost of shipping).

header.#text: Cost analysis

text.#text: In determining whether a public interest exception shall be applied under

header.#text: Criteria for use of public interest exception

text.#text:
consider the short-term and long-term effects of applying such exception on employment within the
			 United States, taking into account information provided by entities that
			 manufacture the articles, materials, or supplies concerned in the United
			 States; and

determine that preserving or increasing employment within the United States is consistent with the
			 public interest.

text.#text:
The entity is the last remaining manufacturer of an item in the United States and that item is
			 considered to be vital for national security purposes by the
The amount of any loan made or guaranteed under this section may not exceed $5,000,000 per entity.

header.#text: Amount of loan or loan guarantee

text.#text:
Each eligible entity receiving a loan or loan guarantee under this section shall use the funds of
			 the loan made or guaranteed only for one or more of the following
			 purposes:

header.#text: Use of funds

text.#text: Increasing its ability to compete for a Government contract for a nonavailable item.
Increasing its ability to produce a nonavailable item.
Increasing its capacity to produce items that are vital to national security.

			 factor used in determining the award of the loan or loan guarantee.
